newsitem.title: CHINA: China futures markets shrink on crackdown.
newsitem.headline: China futures markets shrink on crackdown.

text.p: China's futures markets are shrinking under an official crackdown on the industry, and Beijing remains uncertain what sort of futures industry it wants, analysts said on Monday.
The lack of a futures law despite years of discussion mean that Beijing is forced to use administrative measures to control markets in which irregularities remain rampant, they said.

"Many contracts which very much need to be hedged, including those of coal, steel, sugar and petroleum, have been banned," said one official with a major commodity futures exchange. "This has almost killed off some markets."

"There is no sign the long-awaited futures law will be promulgated in the short term, possibly due to different views among the leadership over futures markets," said a futures analyst. "The poor state of supervision makes China's futures trading more speculation than hedging."
Official statistics show total futures turnover nationwide fell to 2,690.7 billion yuan ($324.2 billion) in the first half of 1996, about half of that in the same period last year.
In Shanghai, home of some of China's largest futures exchanges, turnover dropped to 606 billion yuan, also about 50 percent of last year's level, the Business News said on Monday.
Trading volume of the most active contract in one of the Shanghai commodity exchanges is only thousands of tonnes, making it hard for the exchange to break even, traders said.
The drop in trading volume is a direct result of measures taken by the national regulator, the China Securities Regulatory Commission (CSRC), analysts said.
In March it banned securities brokerages, trust and investment firms and state-run enterprises from trading commodities futures, forcing many traders out of the industry.
Last year it banned treasury bill futures, the most active futures contracts in China, after a series of trading scandals on the Shanghai stock exchange.
All commodity futures exchanges have been ordered to cap daily price movements and total holdings.

"Despite the crackdown, irregularities are rampant, ironically because major contracts have been banned," said the exchange official. "The lower turnover on the market makes it easier for major investors to manipulate the markets."
In addition, analysts said, the use of state funds to speculate in futures markets is still common practice in China.
"Many of us have little sense of responsibility," said one trader. "We get something if we gain and lose nothing if we lose money, because we trade with public funds."
Industry analysts said the key to healthy development of futures markets depended on Beijing deciding what types of markets it wants, if any.

China revived the markets in the early 1990s after a ban of about four decades. At their peak in 1992 and 1993, hundreds of unauthorised futures exchanges were set up, offering everything from beer bottle tops to shoes.
The chaos prompted Beijing to launch a crackdown in early 1994. But it has failed to solve the fundamental issue of what kinds of futures markets it wants, analysts said.
